snippet: A law that gives two votes per share to long-term shareholders in French companies, meant to rein in hostile takeovers, could instead shift power to a different set of interests.
abstract: Steven Davidoff Solomon Deal Professor column observes that France's law granting double voting rights to longterm shareholders, aimed at encouraging committed investing and discouraging hostile takeovers, may have unintended consequences; examines several potential drawbacks, including protection of under-productive boards and shift in power to sovereign investment; notes widespread opposition to rule.
lead_paragraph: A law that gives two votes per share to long-term shareholders in French companies, meant to rein in hostile takeovers, could instead shift power to a different set of interests.

headline.print_headline: France Answers Hostile Bids With the Two-Vote Share
headline.main: France Answers Hostile Bids With the Two-Vote Share
